bioghist.p: Founded in 1743 by Benjamin Franklin, the American Philosophical Society was the first learned society in the United States. For over 250 years, the Society has played an important role in American cultural and intellectual life. Until the mid-nineteenth century, the Society fulfilled the role of a national academy of science, national library and museum, and even patent office. Early members of the Society included Thomas Jefferson, David Rittenhouse, Benjamin Rush, Stephen Peter Du Ponceau, George Washington, and many other figures prominent in American history. Executive Officers of the APS for the period covered by these records included Edwin G. Conklin, Luther P. Eisenhart, George W. Corner, Whitfield J. Bell, Jr., and Herman H. Goldstine.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records from the Executive Office of the American Philosophical Society. Materials include: incoming and outgoing correspondence; minutes and correspondence of various committees, including the Finance Committee and the Executive Committee; correspondence related to professional associations and societies, such as the American Council of Learned Societies and the National Academy of Sciences; and records related to the annual meeting, including lists of reservations, abstracts, and planning documents. The collection contains financial materials, including: budget and annual reports from Society departments; financial statements for the society as a whole and individual funds; publication sales records; some routine financial transactions and purchasing information; legal, insurance and audit files; and information on building restorations and routine improvements and repairs. The collection also includes topical files on particular programs, such as the Franklin papers project, Darwin anniversary celebrations, prizes and awards, and research grants.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
